A very simple clothes hanger that takes about 2 hours to print with 0.3 mm. Assembly
-- It's split into 3 parts so you need super glue to glue them together. Durability
-- It can hold a jacket and a scarf without a problem when using a 0.2 mm rectilinear fill density. Using honeycomb it will be too weak and the hook will break off when using heavier types of clothes. Files
--
  • DWG-file is attached if anyone wants to alter it.
  • STL-file is attached for slicing
  • GCODE-file is attached for direct printing
    • Known issues
    -- The fit between the parts are not optimized for faults in the printing process. The fit works, but it might require sanding in some areas to make a perfect fit.
I tried to recreate the dice from King of Tokyo.

I tend to rotate around the x axis by 45 degrees and the y axis by 35.264 degrees to print on the corner.   5 layer raft.  
Print at 100% for a fair sized die.  125% for a nice large die.  150% for a freaking huge die.  
Print with pla for a great real dice feel.

description.text: Designed for the fitment of a fin with a 4mm thick base tab of suitable design and to be then fibreglassed over completely on each side. Base has been thinned down to 8.2mm (from the standard 9.2mm) to allow for 0.5mm per side of fibreglass lay up.

comments.text: This is great!  I plan to lay up two layers of 6 oz. glass on each side of the fin--I'm not sure how thick 4 layers of glass is once it is laid up, but I would venture to guess that it is more than 0.5 mm.  Would a 6 mm groove be too wide to squeeze into a base that is even a little bit narrower?  Or would that make the insert side walls too thin? 4 mm would be a little thin for a wood insert.  This is such awesome stuff--you're killing it, my man!
comments.author: slidetheorysurfcraft

comments.text: Here is the 6mm slot version.
comments.author: slidetheorysurfcraft

comments.text: Super sweet!  I think this will work great--as long as the material we print them out of is good and strong.  Either way, we could always split the diff and go with a 5mm slot too.  I'll see what we can do about getting one of these printed and see how it works.  I think if we pour resin into the slot when the core is installed, run some fin roving and glass it all up, it should work just fine as long as the base fits snugly into the fin box in the board.  I'd be a little worried if there is too much play side-to-side once in the board.  Thanks again for all your work--I'll be sure to give credit where it is due once we get the ball rolling on this.  You are the man!

An ergonomic tray for when you're playing cards. Since I originally made this for Cards Against Humanity and wanted to put an end to reaching all over for the different piles, I printed multiple in red for discard piles, multiple in green for draw piles, and multiple in black for the black cards. Features:
-Fits about 200 poker-sized playing cards (63 mm x 88 mm)
-Clearances for easy access to remove the cards
-Inclined base to keep the cards in the tray
-Designed to fit on a OneUp print bed (90 mm x 90 mm x 90 mm)
To save on PLA, I printed with 10% infill. I also printed with a 0.5 mm skirt offset to minimize the print area needed.

title: DJI Phantom 3 camera hood sun shade

description.text:
UPDATE: This may occur jello (rolling shutter) effect on very sunny day. My another solution is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:890374 body sun shade. On sunny day avoid halation caused by the sun out of the field of view. Especially effective to avoid flicker by shadow of rotating props. This work (version 4) is inspired by DanHamilton's original work http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:825988.
Designed by OpenScad, model repaired by Microsoft Model Repair Service.

Designed as light as possible (2.3g ABS made), because heavier hood causes "gello effect" on video (that is, vibration of gimbal). This version is almost OK, but may also causes slight gello effect in conditions (wind, fly/ascend/descend speed, prop balance, etc.). I cut off the lower half not to interfere with the gimbal guard when most down (mine is hand made of bamboo... :-) ), and OK when calibrating gimbal, but better take it out when you turn on the bird's power. I take off the lens cap (also Dan's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:817551), turn on power, and put this hood after calibration. No fixing but OK, maybe ABS shrinks and be tighter than designed. If you think it's too loose, use vinyl tape or mending tape. The hood is very FOV tight (94 degree). On my printer, ABS tends to shrink a bit terribly, but don't affect to the view. The hag arm part is very fragile, use a cylinder (31.5mm dia x 20.5mm depth) to protect when not in use.

comments.text: As PLA has a relatively low melting point to other filaments I would recommend using an ABS or Nylon filament. However, I have never worked with nylon before. You might be able to make it work in PLA if you print extra thick and use an inner aluminum heat guard to dissipate heat to a usable but limited point. And as Carbon fiber PLA, it is almost always used in low-stress and low weight applications. And I wouldn't think that those criteria fit with what you want to do.

description.text:
Remix of Eric Lien's Eustathios v2 Spyder belt tensioner. This version is designed to work with 10mm cross bars, 30mm graphite bushings (still uses a 15.9mm diameter opening), and allows the cross rods to be removed without a full disassembly of the x-y gantry. (update: it turns out that the cross bars can be removed from the original belt tensioners by sliding the bar to one side and lifting it out) A version for 8mm cross bars is included, but it has not been printed or tested. This version needs support material to print (the original does not). I would recommend using the original parts, they've been tested on a lot of machines. Once you have a working machine, it's easier to customize it further. Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- Hatchbox Transparent Black ABS
-- Hatchbox Transparent Red ABS
-- 3D Solutech See Through Orange ABS

While giving demos of a GearVR, it became apparent that people have a tendency to unintentionally hold the GearVR so that their hand rubs the touchpad.  This can pause or accidentally select something, confusing the user.  To solve this problem, the GearVR touchpad protector can be taped over the touchpad so the user can hold the GearVR naturally without causing problems.  Note that this is designed for the S6 GearVR.

Slice, print, and tape on!  Note that the curve of the side that touches the GearVR is slightly off center so that it more closely matches the shape of the GearVR itself.  This means it will fit better in one particular orientation.

A remix from thegman fllament guide. I extended some cylinder by 2mm, made some slope around the hole opening that resides near the bearing and extruder gear.  
This is to help the filament go in much easier without being stuck on the heat break. Even the original design, would have the filament stuck at heat break upper end.  
So far this design doesn't have any issues
Print this with support, then file the surface that had any support to make it smooth and flat so that this filament guide won't get stuck between the gear and bearing upon insertion.

Mount your Naze32 / CC3D / multiwii flight controller and receiver in one low-profile box. I designed this around the Turnigy / Flysky 9x receiver, which has a 31mm wide PCB. Hopefully other receivers out there are the same width.  
Many users complain the 9x 8-channel receiver is too bulky for a miniquad. I wanted to save room on my miniquad frame yet still use cheap 9x receivers.  
Later on I hope to make this mostly enclosed.
Mounting holes are m3 sized.

title: Replacement analog stick for the Logitech WingMan Rumble Pad

description.text:
My friend Alex lost one of the detachable analog sticks on his Logitech WingMan Rumble Pad. This is my attempt to recreate it, and my first OpenSCAD project. I've written about the process of putting this together over at the Ponoko blog. Check it out:
http://blog.ponoko.com/2011/05/18/openscad-project-replacement-analog-sticks

The STL files provided will print one or two analog sticks with characteristics similar to the original part. However, the SCAD source has some options that you can change: HOLLOW_POST (default true)
Set to false if you'll drill your own after printing. THUMB_DEPRESSION (default true)
Set to false if you prefer the head of the stick to be flat. ROUNDED_EDGE (default true)
Set to false if you prefer the head of the stick to not have a rounded edge. NUMBER_OF_STICKS (default 2)
Output 1 or 2 sticks for export as STL. Printing
I got the best results when I used ReplicatorG/Skeinforge to flip the model standing up (like a "T") with support materials underneath. It was a pain to clean, but the other way was really blobby on the post.

description.text: I created this bowden mount in order to convert my OneUp to a bowden style hotend. It uses my E3D extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:749998) in a horizontal mounted fashion in combination with the same down at the hotend. Simply print the mount, slide it onto your top rail, and mount your extruder to it. I used about 2 feet of PTFE tubing to connect to my hotend, along with the E3D "groove mount bowden coupler" that they sell on their website. It works really well and allowed me to increase my print speeds pretty dramatically in comparison to the stock hotend configuration.

description.text:
this gear will allow you to turn accurate metric gears on a 7x mini lathe.
It will require an alternate banjo arrangement which i have included photos of and will add drawings or cad files once more testing is complete.
It also provides finer feed, 0.0025(406 tuns/inch) vs 0.0039(256 TPI) with the default 20-80/20-80. And my new banjo is simpler to adjust.
vidio at http://youtu.be/kc-2b6fv8Hk Is this is a worthy solution to a real problem?
If you look at my banjo (please ignore the video production quality.) it is easier to adjust even if you don't use the big gear for production. Would there be enough community interest to justify writing up complete plans and making a better video? I have been using this gear for a while now, even the prototype I printed at lower infill has held up well.
Ernie.

comments.author: thecomputerdewd

description.text:
A challenge for your printer!! "Braq" is a jointed dragon of 42 pieces. Once printed pieces only need an elastic cord 2 to 3mm thick to join them. Check the assembly instructions on this video https://youtu.be/pEerHkxMN2w Click here for more information and source files (blender)
http://diwo.bq.com/dragon-braq/
(in Spanish) Author: http://www.soniaverdu.es/
New articulated head: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:873876

-The pieces have little contact surface to the bed, so it is very important to snug bed printer.
-When setting the gcode file, add adhesion brim or raft. No need to add any additional support because the files include small supports have to eliminate once printed.
-Printed 0.2 mm height, fill density 10% , PLA

comments.text: Hi, thank you for this very cool design. I've printed all parts on my Finder and painted them. Now I tried to create the eyes with Silicon Glue but I allways get bubbles inside them. I've tried heat and even the fridge - but still buggles. Does someone has a hint to fix it? ;-)
comments.author: gerkenz

comments.text:
This was fun to print but gave me a lot of headaches. In hind site i really should have used the supportless files and used my own supports. The supports that are already there leave some scarring. And the wings need a big brim and support.
The tail piecesfile doesnt work well in cura. It doesnt see the big ball/waist, and 3 of the pieces arent touching the plate. You can probably get around this by lowering the whole stl about .2mm or doing the first layer at .3mm. I ended up having to break that file up to get the ball isolated into its own stl for printing. Used 3dbuilder for that.
comments.author: GerbilBite

comments.text: I made one for my nephew, he used hot glue to hold the joints in place. He said that way he can undo it easily and reapply hot glue when he wants to reposition the joints.

comments.text: A better measure to use when talking about filament is weight, because that's what it's sold by. You can easily weigh a roll of filament or a finished model, but you can't easily measure the length of a roll of filament, especially after you've printed it.

comments.text: Position with a slightly negative Z (.5mm? can't remember) to provide better first layers with more contact. Flattening doesn't impact aesthetics or function. I used a brim over a raft cause that first layer is so small and even the gap distance of a raft could cause an issue.  If you need, open the pieces in Meshmixer and export each segment or group of segments to print fewer at a time - if printing PLA, cooling is important due to spherical shapes may invoke curling.  I have a fixed print bed (delta) and babysat the first few mm of print with a frosting spatula following the print head around to manage the curls.

comments.text: I agree it's probably best to print the upper wings one at a time. When I printed both at the same time, shortly after Z=100mm my printer knocked over both wings. I tried again with extra adhesion to the bed; this time, the adhesion was so strong that instead of knocking over the wings, the X carriage got stuck while trying to cross a tiny bead and the X stepper lost sync, causing the printer to extrude strings in the air. I managed to recover, but next time I'll print only one upper wing at a time so that the printer is unlikely to attempt any movement that might cross a bead on the top of the wing.

Using the following options: pattern_rotation = 15
pattern_thickness = 4
build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_overlap = 18
pattern_radius = 9
case_thickness = 1.8
pattern_shape = 6
iphone_version = 2

Lid for soap dispenser so you can use whatever type of soap you wish. As I have a heard time finding refills for this dispenser I just cut the top of my empty refill tank with a soldering iron and designed a lid. Works well.
Abs, no support, 0,5 infill.
A cover for wheel rims with Fiat logo This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9eBnAkqJVrm
A trophy I made for a Hearthstone competition in the Agora Otium game club of Barcelona. It's a remix of Microsoft's 3D trophy and Hearthstone key cap made in Blender.
Design

I cut the key cap in Blender, used the curve deform modifier to adapt it to the surface of the trophy and joined them. I then added a base and an inscription plate made out of simple geometries. I didn't realize until the trophy was printed and finished that the crest was actually an specular image of the Hearthstone crest. I have corrected the model, so other people shouldn't have the same problem.  
Print

I printed the trophy, base and plate independently in a Prusa i3 Hephestos using PLA at 210ºC, 20% infill, 30mm/s and support everywhere. I recommend scaling up the base to 10% more than the other pieces so they fit nicely in their sockets.
Unfortunately, at small scales (10cm total trophy+base height) the extruded text does not print in the plate, so I had to apply a different solution (see below). I will upload an empty plate .stl for future users at some point in the future. Finishing

I sanded the trophy and base with No. 500 water sandpaper and without much patience (results could be much better with more dedication or ABS+acetone bath). The cup handles were covered with epoxy putty and sanded in an (only semi-successful) effort to make them smooth.   
Painting

The model was primed with acrylic black spray and painted with very old and semi-dry Citadel acrylic paint (gold, silver, blue, black and white). The pieces were mounted with epoxy putty and Tamiya plastic glue ( in my hands, it works really well for PLA). For the plate, text was printed to the desired size with a 2D printer and later cut and glued to the plate. I painted over the edges of the tag to blend it with the plate.

title: My Customized Multiline Tag or Keychain

description.text:
A modified Diamond Hotend mount suitable for use with the Rostock max.
Derived from the Diamond Hotend mount from RepRap.me by Kharar.
Some measurements reverse engineered from Rostock MAX Delta 3D printer from by SeeMeCNC This will most likely need to be printed with supports.
It replaces the carriage assembly from the Rostock Max and should be compatible with the V2 and V1, but I have not tested it. If you have one feel free to test it and let me know how it works. I have added some more options, including having bevels and nuts for the arm mounts and options for an IR probe mount.

title: Ponte Vecchio Lusso Piston Removal Tool

description.text:
Edit - Seal guide ring is now included in the downloads. You need this cuff to help insert the middle seal into the cylinder. Edit - Version 3.0 is now uploaded here.
Deeper cup now works better. Tip for use - use a plastic disc between the screw face and the piston to avoid scratching the piston face. This is an stl file for the printing of a portafilter shaped tool that fits into the grouphead of the ponte vecchio lusso espresso machine. It allows for the piston to be removed from the machine by compressing the spring above it, and therefore allowing the pin in the lever assembly to be removed. This then allows the piston to be lowered down and removed.
The tool works with a captured metric nut in its base, and with the screwing in of the metric bolt to press against the piston face.
First, remove the shower screen.
Second, use a suitable material atop the bolt to protect the piston face from scratching.
Third, lock in the portafilter, then screw in the bolt, probably with a socket or wrench. good luck!

I own a 2 group Lusso.  I read on CoffeeSnobs about how to go about removing the piston from the machine.  I measured the existing portafilter and applied the theory of the screw bolt logic to my design.  I then printed it in solid white abs on a stratysis bst 1200 printer.

author: PRUSADIYKIT

description.text:
Having sat on an Ukulele, I decided the best way to avoid pesky repairwork would be to hang the instruments up where I can't crush them. This does the job.
I've included two versions of the object as STL. One has a thicker base in case your ukulele head ends up needing to go through a wall if you try to mount it on the thinner one.  The thin version looks better, and for my instruments at least, I think would work even if I had mounted them on a wall instead of the top of a shelf as I did.
Included is also the Blender file for these, which should be better suited for editing than the STLs.
You will probably want to use a pretty high fill ratio to get the structural strength needed. Otherwise, it's pretty much slice and print.

description.text:
I have NO IDEA why no one has made a printable XY upgrade set yet, so I decided to get the ball rolling. The following pieces (and parts list) should give you just under 12x12 inches of printable space, depending on how/where I decide to mount the bed to these. You can use a smaller/bigger bed, but the belt and rod sizes will vary. You're going to have to play around with M211 to set the XY size. The default FW has this locked out, so here's some firmware for you. Parts you'll need:
X rods: http://www.mcmaster.com/#6112k45
Y rods: http://www.mcmaster.com/#6112K46
Plate: http://www.mcmaster.com/#86825k11
Some GT2 belt. Maybe this? http://www.adafruit.com/products/1184 You may want:
Some high-temp felt to place the bed on the printed parts, like this: http://www.ebay.com/itm/like/361254493104?lpid=82&chn=ps You'll also want to print out some stability feet. There are multiple here, and BIG ones on matrix-precision.com. Todo:
  • Design Y axis mounting bracket. (Or just remix Mach-Chris's: http://www.matrix-precision.com/pages/downloads)
    • HEY EVERYONE, you're going to want to buy the Z axis upgrade from http://www.matrix-precision.com/. This project WILL cut into your build height. (Also consider buying his XY upgrade. It's easier, but whats the fun in that?)

Our first project at Bold Machines back in 2014 was to show that anyone could make all the merchandise for a movie with a 3D printer. The team put together a treatment, developed a story, and imagined characters. We worked with Jose Alves da Silva to make these models real.   
We have a few of these models left to post including the Brooklyn Bridge Robot that we present to you today.  
The Brooklyn Bridge Robot is hidden away inside a secret lab at the corner of Water & New Dock Street near the waterfront.  The lab uses massive batteries to charge the robot via electrical cables from the bridge installed during World War II.  The robot is controlled by Margo's scooter - which she can drive into the base of the robot.  It is a friendly robot - designed to assist in research and heavy rescue.  
Download and assemble The Brooklyn Bridge Robot and make sure to check out all the other models in the Margo series!

This Mechanical Prosthetic Concept was designed for Bold Machines in zBrush by Jose Alves da Silva for use as a development platform for Field Ready, http://www.fieldready.org a global non profit organization specializing in disaster relief efforts. The primary goal was to have a fully 3D printed prosthetic hand that did not require any screws, nuts/bolts or tools to assemble (as those items could be impossible to source in remote areas). We used fabric strips and elastic bands cut from shorts for the testing. The secondary goal was to make the files accessible for development/design changes by others - so it could be improved and modified for specific needs. We invite you to download this model on Thingiverse, test, and modify it. Share photos of your print please!

The griping  ability is quite good. Kind of an expanded two finger approach. Fantastic idea. I am an e-NABLE volinteer. I plan to work on developing this approach. I can see the advantage for remote sites with limited resources.

Here is a model from our archives. Developed By Bin Li, this epic model prints beautifully at Z18 scale.   
We asked Bin Li a few questions about his background and process.  
Can you describe your journey as a designer - how did you get started and what motivated you?  
The journey started late. In fact I didn't start art training until college, where I was studying computer science around 2005. But then weird enough, a close encounter with drawing and painting opened up a whole new world to me. I decided to be an artist to create and to fulfill my vision. 3D Animation and Games was the fuel of my passion, that's why I went to Ringling College of Art and Design to study Computer animation. Since that, I worked as a 3d  modeling and designing artist.   
What was the creative process like for this model?  
It started as eagerness to create something with power and impact. I pitched an idea of a prehistory creature and a journey on a ship, using a classic book in the public domain as an example.   
After that, everything went smoothly. I re-read the book, gathered visual reference and other images of existing designs. Explored a few sketches of a new designs of the submarine and the squid first, then did more sketches of the overall composition and pose of the sculpture. After the 2d sketches were approved, I started 3d Sculpting. From rough to refined, until things were finessed and ready to print.  
Any background on why you chose this model?   
I enjoy doing creatures. Hard surface model is a lot of fun as well. So this one is a good mix.  
Describe any challenges you had in getting a successful print (tricks of the trade)?  
The pose of the tentacles and waves gave some trouble. They had to be modified a few times after test prints.   
What advice do you have for someone interested in designing 'one piece' prints?  
Test print in early stage so problems don't come near the deadline.  
Thanks Bin Li!  
Bin Li rew up in China and went to Florida in 2008. He got a BFA for computer animation in 2012, went to Digital Domain working on animated feature film. Moved to New York City in 2013, worked on visual effects on TV commercials and worked at MakerBot from 2014 to 2015.  
Go forth, download, and print it. Make sure to share pictures of it on Thingivers so we can all revel in the glory of this epic model.

I had some binding issues with the bushings and got tired of oiling my x-axis, so I made a x axis which uses 608 bearings to ride on the smooth rods. Note that this has a bunch of issues.  
The vertical bearings on the belt side need to be attached with something that will be flush with the back so the belt can fit back there.
The bearings have a little play, and may need to be moved slightly.  I just wrapped some tape around the outside of the diagonal bearings to make em a bit fatter.
It needs a long hot end (the makergear is ~5mm to short) to reach below the carriage.  I just modified the makergear to pull this off.
NOTE: The STL is the SAE version.  to regenerate the stl as metric, just download the scad file and put it in the prusa mendel dir (configured for metric).  Adjust the existing x-carriage scad (comment out the last line) and then open the x-carriage-608.scad in openscad.

• Attach bearings as shown
  • Attach hot end
  • Pray
  • Print smoothly!

description.text: The Gowanus Monster. Legend tells of a beast that haunts the darky depths of Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal. Unsuspecting hipsters who dare to approach the edges of the canal late at night are thought to have looked into the eye of the beast - then hypnotized by the strange glow of the eyes, have jumped into the canal. If they are lucky they are washed up near Whole Foods with no memory of what happened... As part of the Margo Series - the Gowanus Monster is the Aquatic Robotic Vehicle (ARV) that searches for an ancient underwater city - rumored to be located near the Gowanus Canal. Developed by Mr. Walthersnap, the ARV uses echo location and vacuum tube technology to navigate. Gowanus Canal: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gowanus_Canal Printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2x (ABS) and a MakerBot Replicator Z18 (PLA). Designed by Sean Charlesworth: http://opus5.complex88.com/

Designed and modeled for Bold Machines by Sean Charlesworth Pins by whpthomas from his PLA Cube Gears for Replicator 2:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38712 All files have been run through mesh repair and are print-ready. Most parts print wihtout support. PARTS NEEDED: body bottom x1 5% / 2 shells / raft
body top x1 5% / 2 shells / raft
body-head pin x8 5% / 2 shells
eye window x2 10% / 1 shell
fin side x1 10% / 1 shell
fin top x1 10% / 1 shell
head x1 5% / 2 shell / support / raft usually not needed
porthole x6 10% / 1 shell
prop x2 0% / 1 shell / slower speed recommended
prop housing x2 10% / 1 shell
tentacle 01 - 04 x1 each 5% / 2 shells / raft & support - slower speed may help, have had some success printing without support
tentacle pin x4 10% / 2 shells / raft
platform x1 10% / 1 shell
platform arm x1 10% / 1 shell
platform front cradle x1 10% / 1 shell
platform rear cradle x1 10% / 1 shell OPTIONAL: porthole insert x6 - used as a different color window insert for portholes 10% / 1 shell
eye window DUAL frame - used with insert for a dual print eye window 10% / 1 shell
eye window DUAL insert 10% / 1 shell DIRECTIONS:
  • Insert pegs into body bottom
  • Put side fins on pegs
  • Put top body on pegs
  • Insert pegs into head (make sure to remove support material)
  • Put head on body assembly
  • Glue in: top fin and portholes
  • Glue on eye windows, there's no alignment key, so rotate to desired angle
  • Put props in housing, they will friction fit so they can rotate
  • Glue prop assemble to head
  • Gently insert pins in tentacles (make sure to remove support material) & snap into head - order does not matter

  • If porthole inserts are used, print in contrasting color and glue into portholes

  • Glue platform arm to base
  • Glue front and rear cradles to arm. The arm is marked with 'F' to indicate front position. Cradles are marked 'F' and 'R' for front and rear. Arrow next to letter indicates front-facing orientation for installation
  • Front cradle sits underneath the head

For this project, I challenged my students to design a catapult! I really wanted to design a project that would include several areas of study (other than CAD) and this seemed to do the trick. This project included History, Math, Science, and English (along with CAD of course). The first thing I had my students do was do research on the history of catapults as well as how the designs of catapults changed (or remained the same) throughout the ages. I then had my students write a short essay about a certain type of catapult, who used that catapult, what era this catapult was from, and why the design of this catapult was successful. Finally, I had my students begin designing their catapults and required them to use some math and physics to come up with a design that would best utilize force and trajectory. The project was really fun, and the students had a blast! I don't even think they realized all of the things they were learning during this project. Here is a link to one of the student's projects:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:765605 And here is a video of one of the launches:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xpOv4b8-XdU
Students used Autodesk Inventor to design this project.

I included my original project write-up if anyone is interested in doing something similar.  I have since changed some things about the project, but this should give everyone the basic idea.  
As always, if you have any questions please ask!

Project Description *Objectives: I really wanted to design a project that would include several areas of study (other than CAD) and this seemed to do the trick. This project included History, Math, Science, and English (along with CAD of course). See description for more details. *Audiences: Juniors & Seniors participated in this project. Their skill level ranged from beginner to intermediate. *Preparation: Students should already have some knowledge in using the CAD modeling programs. Necessary technology will be a computer with software, a 3D printer, and some rubber bands. *Steps:The first thing I had my students do was do research on the history of catapults as well as how the designs of catapults changed (or remained the same) throughout the ages. I then had my students write a short essay about a certain type of catapult, who used that catapult, what era this catapult was from, and why the design of this catapult was successful. Finally, I had my students begin designing their catapults and required them to use some math and physics to come up with a design that would best utilize force and trajectory. Results: I ended up dividing my students up into two design groups. They worked together as a team to create their catapults. I had two varying designs, but both worked well. The "Catabow" design was the overall "winner" and was able to shoot the projectile almost 30 feet. The project was really fun, and the students had a blast! I don't even think they realized all of the things they were learning during this project.

description.text: I made this chess set for my Grandfather\'s 90th birthday. I laser it cut it out of 3mm birch plywood and stained the dark pieces. The board is alternating etched & bare squares. Now that I\'m back from the trip, I\'m getting around to posting the designs up. I hope to make another set, maybe with etched or a scored pattern for the dark pieces, rather than having to stain them and wait for all that boring drying. I designed it in SketchUp. First I snagged some standard looking models for chess pieces from the warehouse. Then I scaled the king to a height of 85mm and scaled the rest to match (pretty closely) the same base size as the king. I drew two 90-degree planes through each one and made them components. Then I intersected one face of the plane with the rest of the model and got the lines I wanted. I pulled out that new face to 1/2 the width of the ply and did the same to the other side. Intersecting the two parts got me the lines for the notches. A good bit of twiddling later, I used the <a href=\"SVG">http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:845\">SVG from SketchUp faces plugin to export one face of each of the parts. I\'ve noticed the newer version gives much smoother paths, I think there are some gaps in the current version of the files I\'m uploading. Note: I've updated the svg files using the newer version of the SVG plugin, which does a single path. It cuts much cleaner. I have not, however, updated the EPS with all the pieces laid out on a single board. I'm leaving it here, just in case someone wants it.

Laser cut the pieces, twice. Stain or somehow color the dark pieces. Fit them together and glue. Take note of the \"intentional\" key-ing of the bases, the 3-tab will only fit one way. The center tab is half a millimeter bigger than all the other tabs. For the board, cut it out and then run the black squares over it at a 100% speed, 100% power to get a nice golden color. I've added pictures of the board now that the second copy is done. They're up on etsy now, if you'd rather buy than build, see http://www.etsy.com/listing/39512877/laser-cut-chess-set

description.text:
A variant for the Ultimaker Z-stage with height and tilt adjustment.
The printing platform is supported by 3 adjustment screws.
You pay a little stability but you get a tiltfree printplatform

• Print the (4) parts , Optional: tap M4 thread in the (adjustment) screwholes
  • Remove the original Z print platform and the plate between the Z legs.
  • Mount the brackets and the XY stabilistor with M3x40
  • Screw 3x M4 (adjustment) screws
  • Glue on each screw a magnet.
  • Glue 3 magnets on the downside of the print platform.
  • Level the platform with the screws and readjust the upper Z endswitch
  • Redefine your start.gcode file according to the new start print height.

On pages 92 and 93 of the June issue of Popular Mechanics, a piece slipped past the editors titled, "Phrases You Never Want to Hear in a Man's Workshop" with quips such as, "pilot holes are for sissies" and "Please don't tell me we missed Ellen."  
We understand that the editors meant for the piece to be titled "Phrases You Never Want to Hear in Any Workshop" and we have kindly created a simple edit tool for readers for this purpose.  
In addition, "pilot holes are for sissies" has been replaced with "pilot holes are for newbies," because no one really uses the term "sissies" anymore and it is probably confusing to most readers.  
We are not quite sure what the intent was with the comment about Ellen. We have to agree that it would normally be unfortunate to hear that an episode of The Ellen DeGeneres Show had been missed, but in this day and age, we have DVR and Hulu for that kind of thing. As such, the comment has been replaced with "I love how these solder fumes smell!"  
To use this edit tool, simply print it out as is. It is a large print, so you might need to print in sections and attach it together somehow.  
Take the blank block set, dip it in white ink or paint, and carefully place it so that the largest blank block fits over the section title "Phrases You Never Want to Hear in a Man's Workshop." With luck, the other two blocks at the end should line up to blank out the phrases we are editing here.  
Next, allow the ink or paint to dry adequately.  
Next, take the text block set and lightly dip it in your choice of colored ink or paint, such as black to match the rest of the section. Be careful not to get too much ink or paint. You might want to test it out on a blank piece of paper to make sure only the text is transferred.   
When you are satisfied with how much paint you have on the text block, once again carefully line up the largest block so that you will imprint a new title with much better wording.  
Thanks to all the Makerspaces and Hackerspaces out there that place an intelligent and thriving focus on diversity. The Maker Movement has nothing to do with "men's" workshops.  
Thanks to Popular Mechanics editors, because I am sure they will get around to making a correction. This is important especially since the June 2015 issue is a special issue, titled "Maker Nation," that focuses on the Maker Movement. We certainly do not want any readers becoming confused and thinking it is gender specific in any way.  
If you print this out and edit the June 2015 issue of Popular Mechanics, post a pic.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eVHkuGzQuLa
Just a basic extrusion of "Groot".

There have been tons of graphics rendering programs developed over the years. Likewise, there are tons of graphics books out there in the world showing you how to use those systems. One such system is OpenGL. As OpenGL is utilized for everything from game development to rendering of body tissue, there are plenty of examples, and models, demonstrating how to do very interesting things. This thing uses the current version of the Granule rendering system being developed in OpenScad, and renders one of the well known samples from OpenGL called "bezmesh". I found an article here: http://www.opengl.org/resources/code/samples/mjktips/grid/index.html and used the bezier mesh control points, unchanged, to render this thing. The picture includes the entirety of the source code needed to render this thing, of course, not including the libraries files. The key function is the bezierMeshSurface() module. It takes 4 bezier control point curves, and does interpolation between them. For the math hearted, the function evaluates along the curves simultaniously (u=0:1), and at each step forms a new curves from the 4 evaluated points, and then renders that curve. Along the way, the bezier.scad library gained a couple more new modules to help render bezier curves using arrays, and honoring all three axis. The other picture, of the arch thing is just another set of control points calling the same Bezier Mesh function. For creating that one, I was thinking of what kind of curves I would need to make something to fit within the web of my hand. It's essentially a saddle. Saddles are good for many things, including joints between bones. So, this shows how easy they are to create with just a few curves. At the current iteration, the library relies on the granule renderer, which is about the slowest way in the world to do things. Thus, it creates a bazillion vertices and polygons, which makes it fairly impractical for printing, although it can be done. The next version will use faces, and thus reduce the vertex and polygon count. Then this tool will be practical. But for now, you can see pretty pictures. UPDATE: Added a couple of pictures of a piece that I actually printed. The .stl is included. It is 3Mb! I don't know how the Thingiverse renderer will handle that. It's an interesting point to me. Perhaps for things that are generated, the .scad file is a better transport mechanism than .stl. Since OpenScad is available everywhere, it's just one step away from 'uncompressing' a design from the .scad to the .stl.

1) Change a couple of parameters (usteps, zsteps)
2) Hit 'F5'
3) Look at the pretty picture
4) Rejoice! If you have the patience, you can probably actually hit 'F6' and compile the thing, and send it for output to an .stl file. I did this on another curve and it took 1 hour 47 minutes. So, you have time to watch a movie.

comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: 'lack of variable reassignment'...  Yah, I would characterize it as lack of global state management.  You can use 'assign()' to set state, but it only applies to the local subtree you're about to render.  So, it's not the traditional lexically scoped 'variables' that you have in standard languages.
comments.author: TeamTeamUSA

comments.text: Break is on my wish list too. :)
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: I hope they are making progress on that python-OpenSCAD mashup, pySCAD.
comments.author: TeamTeamUSA

comments.text: Yes, pretty much a voxel.  I wanted to use granule because that's the source of the plastic filaments that we're using.  I also had the thought that if I had a mahine that could deposit granules, instead of stretched lines of filament, that would be a nifty thing.  So, it's part speculative aspiration.
comments.author: TeamTeamUSA

comments.text: I printed this at a .35mm line thickness.  So, in the model, I selected 1/.35 as the grain size (2.857).  By doing this, my printer (Up!) pretty much made a nice solid thickness.  It does try to print the various edges of things, and gets more blocky than needed.  If I print at 0.4, or higher than my granule size, it will come out smoother.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: On the issue of .scad vs .stl I guess it would depend on what is scarce: storage/bandwidth or processing power/time. Must be closely related to the insight that intelligence and data compression are strongly related. Heady stuff!
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: DNA vs sending you a body.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Doing great work here... keep it up!
comments.author: Renosis

comments.text: Thanks.  I'm probably a couple of experimentation sessions away from making this useful for the general public.  The function interfaces will remain the same, just the back end face generation part needs to change.
comments.author: Renosis

comments.text: By faces do you mean multiple polygon() calls?
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yes, exactly.  Think of this.  Triangulate your surface, generating a mesh.  Now, for each triangle of that mesh, find the surface normal (which direction is the thing facing).
comments.author: TeamTeamUSA

comments.text: I tried a similar approach in sage to convert a surface into a solid without success. :(
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Current approach is to draw the poly (triangle) and use linear_extrude to get the desired thickness.  Then, position that poly where it needs to be.  I'm not concerned there will be gaps as the coordinates of the vertices will be exactly the same for neighbors.  I am concerned there will be surface cracks (not gaps) where the thickness of the material bends away from the neighboring facet.  We'll see how it goes.
comments.author: TeamTeamUSA

comments.text: Since you have the normals for all the neighbors, isn't the crack going to be extrudeLength*sin(angle between normal1 and normal2) wide, or some scalar cousin thereof depending on where you extruded from?
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Yep.  When printing with granules, this would be the equivalent of antialiasing.  I've experimented with some fixed size expansions like 20% and whatnot.  It does tend to fill in the cracks.  I've also thought of using spheres instead of cubes for the granules, but that's a lot more calculation intensive at the mement.
comments.author: syvwlch

title: LCD 12864 Case and Holder for acrylic frame or other 6/8mm box frame

description.text:
The licence is inherited from the distributor of the "Sainsmart 12864 LCD case"  
If your PCB Looks anything like the one provided in Model 2, you're better of with this 12864 Case. You can "tape-measure" the distances in the free version of SketchUp-Make.

Update 10/10/2017:
Fixed the issues with the slicing and increased the gap for the SD-Card on the two new cases: added 6mm and 8mm case as requested by several Users.

The M3s are locked into the edges of the Case so the screws of the cover will stick perfectly. I created some "Infill" to make sure the model can be printed without. Careful while removing the bricks.   
Have Fun using it, looks great and works fine.

comments.text: The two main parts are not manifold, and repairs seem to screw things up (such as holes disappearing). Is there a fixed version?

Should fit nicer now, the screws will hold it in place anyway.
Best Regards
Collin
comments.author: billsey

comments.text: I have been looking for a design to my liking and I think yours is it.  I am new to this and just getting my feet wet. Personally I don't like the display mounting screws being external as I have seen in most of the designs. The screws can be mounted from the back with self tapping screws where a little smaller hole is made that does not come to the surface. The hole for the contrast pot to me is not necessary. I like to see clean face plates. I would be happy if you could make the changes as an alternative design and I'm sure other people would like it too.  Thank you for your effort and hope this not too much to ask.

author: Malathar

description.text: This is a 6x5 mechanical display. The pixels are on 26mm pitches in both directions. It is designed to be driven by a jacquard-style punch card reader (such as three of these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:101077), although it can be adapted to any mechanical control system desired. This is the display only. For further details, see the full write-up about it here: http://www.chrisfenton.com/the-pixelweaver/

The rows are designed to be bolted to a frame that is 225mm wide, and the rows are spaced 26mm apart vertically. Everything is to be assembled with suitable M3 nuts and bolts. This was all printed on an original Replicator 2, typically with 2 shells, 0.25mm layer height and 25% infill.
  • Print out 5 row brackets.
  • Print out 30 pixels.
  • Print out 30 ratchet arms.
  • Print out 2 row aligners.
  • Acquire 12 x 3mm brass rods to serve as row-wise axles for the pixels and ratchet arms.
  • Print out one 'pixel knife array'.
  • Assemble display and bolt to suitable frame.
  • Insert M3 nuts and 8mm M3 bolts into the end of each ratchet arm.
  • Attach control strings to each lever and attach them to a suitable control device, such that they are lifted out of the way of the knife array to control the toggling of the pixels as desired.
  • Attach the pixel knife array to a suitable source of reciprocating linear motion, with an approximate travel of 50mm, such that it pulls the ratchet arms backwards and rotates the pixels 90 degrees in the event that the ratchet arms have not been lifted slightly by their control strings.
  • When transitioning between frames, pre-compute which pixels need to toggle to transition from one state to another, and control the ratchet arms as desired.
